stream_context.summary: Kaze continues greybox development on the castle-side Snowman Cave area, focusing on enemy behavior (snowmen), platforming layout, elevator/camera shake tuning, and visual placeholders. He also discusses console-testing workflow improvements, a planned public Course 1 demo with structured feedback collection, and personal/logistical context: his daughter is expected to be born in ~5 days, potentially pausing streams.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains multiple documentary-relevant reveals: imminent birth and likely streaming pause, explicit philosophy about staying within original N64 limits (64MB ROM) as a creative constraint, plans to release a Course 1 demo with formal player-feedback collection, and concrete workflow/tech updates (rapid N64 testing, shadow system redesign, elevator/camera shake settings).

findings.summary: Kaze identifies an AI/behavior bug: the block/enemy attack logic only checks lateral distance, and needs an additional vertical-distance check so it behaves correctly across height differences.

He plans to fix incorrect-looking shadows by making Mario’s shadow a separate object that finds the floor independently, avoiding edge cases when Mario is standing/jumping on other objects that confuse floor detection.

Snowman Cave is being designed as a set of distinct “rooms/sections,” including (1) a climbable slide section with a snowman attacking while you ascend, (2) platforms over a void for vertical traversal, and (3) a missing-but-required final slide down; he wants the area’s enemy theme to be mostly/only snowmen.

Visuals are explicitly placeholder/“butt ugly” during layout work; he rejects wood block aesthetics for the ice cave and experiments with rocks/ice pillars, considering reflective ice and placing objects under the ice for visual interest.

He demonstrates a faster real-hardware iteration loop: after setup, he can click a batch file to deploy and test directly on N64 quickly, though he notes he currently has noticeable input/display delay when playing this way.

He tunes elevator motion/shake: the current shake is excessive, so he adds/adjusts magnitude/detail settings, removes unused shake code, and considers shifting shake from the elevator object to the camera only; he tests different sounds for the elevator/oily-water pit interaction.

He continues to iterate platforming readability and fairness in the climb section by adjusting slopes, spacing, wall push-out behavior, and warp placement to make routes more forgiving while keeping “many ways to climb” (no single correct route).

He outlines a near-term milestone plan: next stream he will build the void-heavy slide section (likely needing surreal/half-clear backgrounds for a trippy look), then an end room; finishing these would complete the platforming for the area’s “second star,” before final art polish.

Kaze says his daughter is likely to be born in five days; he may not be able to stream next week depending on hospital timing. He notes the baby is a girl and mentions the name “Reyna/Reyna” in passing as the decided name.

He emphasizes a self-imposed authenticity constraint: even if modern tools/hardware allow effectively infinite space, he wants to stay within original-era limitations (he cites 64MB as a hard ceiling) to avoid the project feeling like “cheating,” which also affects decisions like avoiding expensive voice lines.
findings.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?

findings.summary: Kaze describes the active team workflow: Biobak reviews and improves models after Kaze finishes them; Badub composes music; Zeina helps with concept art and especially animations; occasional community members contribute small one-off assets/ideas.

He plans a Course 1 demo release and a structured Google Doc questionnaire so players can provide detailed feedback on physics and camera feel; the goal is to make small adjustments until movement/camera “feel just right.”

He’s hiring a video editor to increase output: he pays about $16 per minute of finished video (~$200 for a typical edit), and believes higher throughput could significantly grow the channel (potentially to 1M subscribers) while also supporting dev visibility.
He reiterates the scale of Nintendo enforcement against his work, claiming Nintendo took down about 70 of his videos in the past, framing it as strong hostility toward his Mario modding content.
findings.quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

biobak.summary: Kaze states Biobak regularly reviews Kaze’s completed models and makes them “look a lot better,” implying an iterative art pipeline where Kaze blocks in assets and Biobak polishes/optimizes them.

badub.summary: Kaze confirms Badub is responsible for composing music for the project and is an ongoing dependency for OST/atmosphere needs (he references needing music to keep stream chat sane and later mentions Badub explicitly as the composer).

zeina.summary: Kaze says Zeina contributes concept art and is primarily handling animations, which he calls the “biggest” area of her contribution. She also appears briefly in-person at home during the stream, showing real-life overlap with production logistics.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?
memorable_quotes.context: He explains why he refuses to rely on expanded ROM/memory even if it’s technically possible, tying authenticity and respect for the N64’s constraints to the project’s identity.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.
memorable_quotes.context: He summarizes the scale of Nintendo takedowns against his prior Mario-related content, reinforcing the long-running legal/corporate pressure around his work.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: In five days, my daughter is likely going to be born, meaning I might not be able to stream next week.
memorable_quotes.context: A major personal milestone that will likely affect the project schedule and the team’s near-term cadence.

key_stories.title: Greyboxing the Snowman Cave into a multi-section star challenge
key_stories.summary: Kaze works in an intentionally ugly/placeholder state to validate platforming first, then plans to return for visuals. He sketches the Snowman Cave as a small set of distinct traversal “rooms,” identifies that it still feels incomplete, and commits to adding a void-heavy slide and an end/treasure room to complete the second star’s route.
key_stories.challenge: The Snowman Cave only has a couple of interesting sections so far, and the current look (e.g., wood blocks) undermines the ice-cave fantasy.
key_stories.process: He iterates on room concepts (climb with snowman attacks, void platforms), rejects mismatched materials, tests traversal routes, tweaks slopes/spacing/warp placement to reduce unfair push-outs, and outlines next steps (slide + end room).
key_stories.outcome: The climb section becomes playable with multiple viable routes; next stream is planned to build the slide and finalize the second star’s platforming path before art polish.
key_stories.key_quote: Next time, I'm gonna do the slide… and then after that… that would be the second star's platforming finished.

key_stories.title: Choosing authenticity: staying inside N64-era limits
key_stories.summary: Kaze explicitly frames technical constraint as part of the creative mission: the hack should feel like it could have existed in the N64 era. He resists “infinite” modern expansions and cites ROM space and voice lines as expensive resources that must be treated as scarce.
key_stories.challenge: Modern tools and flashcarts could allow more memory/ROM, but using it risks undermining the project’s premise and audience trust.
key_stories.process: He sets a hard ceiling (he cites 64MB), avoids memory-heavy features like extensive voice lines, and treats resource budgeting as an ongoing design requirement rather than a late optimization pass.
key_stories.outcome: A clear guiding principle emerges that can be used to justify cuts, prioritization, and the project’s “respectful but new” positioning in the documentary.
key_stories.key_quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?

key_stories.title: Planning a Course 1 demo to tune ‘feel’ via structured player feedback
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes an upcoming demo release (Course 1) primarily as a development instrument rather than a marketing beat. He wants broad feedback on physics and camera to make small, high-impact adjustments that are hard to validate alone.
key_stories.challenge: Movement and camera ‘feel’ require many subjective micro-decisions that can’t be perfected purely by developer intuition.
key_stories.process: He plans a public demo and a Google Doc questionnaire so players can comment on specific aspects (physics, camera, and related tuning).
key_stories.outcome: An actionable feedback pipeline is defined; if executed, it could lock in core feel early and reduce late-stage rework.
key_stories.key_quote: Ideally what I want is to get as much feedback as possible so I can make minuscule adjustments and get the physics feeling just right.

open_questions.topic: Shadow system redesign as a separate object
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to decouple Mario’s shadow from Mario by making it a separate object that finds the floor independently, to avoid issues when Mario interacts with moving objects or nonstandard floor detection cases.
questions: What specific shadow failures were happening (e.g., elevators, moving platforms, jump interactions), and how often did they occur in playtests?
What does ‘separate object’ mean in your engine terms—does it run its own floor queries, collision checks, or room/sector logic?
Did this change force any other refactors (render order, performance, animation timing), and how did you validate it on real hardware?

open_questions.topic: Snowman Cave: final structure, pacing, and star mission intent
open_questions.context: He has a climb section with snowman attacks and void platforms, but says it still needs a slide down and an end room (possibly a treasure/coin room) to complete the second star’s platforming.
questions: What is the intended emotional arc of this star (tension, recovery, payoff) across the climb → void → slide → treasure room sequence?
Why the decision to keep the enemy roster mostly ‘only snowmen’ here—theme consistency, performance, readability, or narrative tone?
How do you decide whether a jump is ‘too much’ in RTYI—what are your internal rules for punishment (fall damage vs reset vs checkpoint)?

open_questions.topic: Void slide visuals and ‘trippy’ background plan
open_questions.context: Kaze expects the slide to be mostly in void and mentions needing surreal/half-clear backgrounds so it doesn’t look empty and feels intentionally strange.
questions: What references are you using for the void-slide look (other games, existing SM64 spaces, concept art)?
How will you prevent the ‘void’ from reading as unfinished (fog planes, skyboxes, translucency tricks, silhouettes)?
Are there N64 rendering constraints (fill rate, overdraw, alpha sorting) that limit how ‘half-clear’ backgrounds can be implemented?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to release a Course 1 demo and collect detailed player feedback via a Google Doc to fine-tune physics and camera.
questions: What exact build will be in the Course 1 demo (one star, multiple stars, hub access, options menu), and what do you want players to stress-test?
How will you translate qualitative feedback (‘feels slippery’) into concrete parameter changes—do you have a tuning checklist or metrics?
Will you segment feedback by hardware (real N64 + EverDrive vs emulator) given the latency/performance differences you mentioned?

open_questions.topic: Resource budgeting and the 64MB authenticity constraint
open_questions.context: Kaze states ROM space is one of the most limited resources and he does not want to exceed 64MB, partly to avoid accusations of ‘cheating’ the N64 premise; he calls voice lines particularly expensive.
questions: Is 64MB a hard technical target for RTYI’s final ROM, or a public-facing ‘rule’ you aim to meet even if it costs features?
What are the top current ROM/memory consumers (textures, music, geometry, code), and what’s your budgeting strategy?
How do you balance authenticity vs player experience when a modern expansion (more music/voice) would clearly improve presentation?
